block.p: MANHATTAN: APPLE TOURS CRITICIZED The city's Consumer Affairs Department has accused New York Apple Tours of lying to customers since the bus company was ordered off the road. The department said Friday that Apple Tours employees have told tourists that Apple Tours was the same company as New York Double Decker Buses. Double Decker is a separate company. It agreed to honor Apple Tours tickets sold before the May 31 suspension of Apple Tours' license. The president of Apple Tours, Hayim Grant, above, denied the charge.

PEEKSKILL: BEAR VISITS A 250-pound black bear was seen wandering around the downtown area for four hours early yesterday. The police got their first report of the bear about 5:30 a.m., and at 6:15 a.m., he was spotted up the tree near the Assumption Church on Union Avenue. The animal was tranquilized and was to have been released yesterday in the Catskills.

FALLSBURG: PRISONER MOVED Arthur Shawcross, a serial killer who spent the last nine months in solitary confinement for selling artwork on the Internet, is back in the general prison population. Mr. Shawcross, who was convicted of killing 11 Rochester-area women a decade ago, was released Saturday from solitary confinement at Sullivan Correctional Facility, where he is serving 250 years to life. Mr. Shawcross created art and signed autographs and gave the items to friends outside prison, who sold them on eBay, an Internet auction site. In return, the friends said they would buy Mr. Shawcross items he needed.

ALBANY: DISASTER AID SOUGHT FOR FARMS Gov. George E. Pataki has asked the Clinton administration to provide emergency disaster aid to farm families in 30 New York counties where hailstorms and heavy rains have caused crop losses. The move would make growers in the counties eligible for up to $500,000 in low-interest loans. The counties are Albany, Broome, Chenango, Columbia, Cortland, Delaware, Dutchess, Erie, Fulton, Greene, Herkimer, Jefferson, Lewis, Monroe, Montgomery, Niagara, Oneida, Onondaga, Orange, Orleans, Rensselaer, Saratoga, Schenectady, Schoharie, Steuben, Tioga, Ulster, Washington, Wayne and Yates.

BRIDGEPORT: CHARITABLE GIFTS QUESTIONED A state organization that raises money for charity from state employees is being criticized again. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport and the New York-based Catholic League are upset that Catholics for a Free Choice, which supports several causes contrary to church doctrine, is one of the groups eligible for money from the organization, the Connecticut State Employees' Campaign for Charitable Giving. The campaign has also been criticized for dropping the Boy Scouts of America.

TRENTON: DIETARY LAWS New Jersey is poised to become the first state to enact a law regulating the sale of food prepared under Muslim dietary laws. The bill, which passed the State Legislature unanimously, would put New Jersey at the head of efforts to place Islam on an equal legal footing with Christianity and Judaism, The Star-Ledger in Newark reported yesterday. The New Jersey bill offers protection from pricing fraud and requires producers to follow the rules. The bill is headed to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for signing.

HACKENSACK: FASTER TOLLS Tollbooths will be removed in the E-ZPass-only lanes at the George Washington Bridge's lower level and at the toll plaza from the Palisades Interstate Parkway. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the change was a first step toward allowing E-ZPass users to go through toll checkpoints at highway speeds, The Record in Hackensack reported yesterday. Toll scanners would be mounted above the lane, the newspaper reported. Such a system would permit E-ZPass users to drive through without slowing to 5 miles per hour, as they have to now.

WATER POLLUTION FORUM The legislative director of the State Water Resources Commission, John L. Turner, will speak about Long Island ground water and efforts to ban M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive that contaminates water supplies. North Hempstead Town Hall, 220 Plandome Road, Manhasset, 7 p.m. Information: (203) 327-9786.

LANDMARKS PANEL HEARINGS The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission will consider several actions, including a study of landmark status for the New York Life Insurance Company building at 51 Madison Avenue in Manhattan and a vote on whether to grant landmark status to Astor Court, in the Bronx Zoo. Commission headquarters, Public Hearing Room, 100 Old Slip between Water and South Streets, Manhattan, 9 a.m. Information: (212) 487-6782.
SKAKEL TRIAL HEARING A hearing in the murder case of Michael Skakel is scheduled for the Judicial District Courthouse, 123 Hoyt St., Stamford, Conn., at 10 a.m.

SMOKING PENALTIES A public hearing on a proposed Suffolk County law to penalize minors for buying or possessing cigarettes or rolling papers. H. Lee Dennison building, 100 Veterans Memorial Highway, Hauppauge, N.Y., 9:30 a.m. Information: (631) 853-4088.
RENT INCREASE VOTE A final decision by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board on the largest proposed rent increases in four years.

LONG ISLAND POWER AUTHORITY The authority's trustees will vote on awarding a contract for an electric cable under Long Island Sound from New Haven to Shoreham. Teleconference Center, Omni Building, 333 Earle Ovington Blvd., Uniondale, 10 a.m. Information: (516) 222-7700.
